urn:contentItem:6DTC-6753-S75C-S55C-00000-00Kyushu University Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Cacao agroforestry adoption by smallholder farmers and forest loss prevention in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize)2025-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYKyushu University Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Cacao agroforestry adoption by smallholder farmers and forest loss prevention in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize)


2025 JAN 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Fukuoka, Japan, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Unsustainable land use practices have led to increased forest loss rates. Implementing cacao agroforestry can reduce forest loss by preventing the clear-cutting of forests for monoculture plantations."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Kyushu University, "However, research is needed on its effectiveness in preventing forest loss and the factors influencing its adoption between full-time and part-time farmers. Here, we address these gaps in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize, by using Mahalanobis distance matching to compare forest loss in cacao agroforestry concession, forest reserve, and de-reserve areas and analyzing social data of 187 households. The results suggest that the odds of forest loss in the cacao agroforestry concession area are approximately 16% higher than in the Maya Mountain North Forest Reserve. In comparison, they are 85% lower than in the de-reserved areas. We also report differences in the factors influencing agroforestry adoption between part-time and full-time farmers."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Successful cacao agroforestry adoption requires considering the differences that exist between farmers' categories."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Cacao agroforestry adoption by smallholder farmers and forest loss prevention in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize. Ambio, 2024. Ambio can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Ambio - www.springerlink.com/content/0044-7447/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Santos Daniel Chicas, Dept. of Agro-Environmental Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, 744 Motooka Nishi-ku, Fukuoka, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Nobuya Mizoue, Tetsuji Ota, Khin Thu Wint Kyaw, Miguel Conrado Valdez, Jonas 0stergaard Nielsen and Chi-Farn Chen.
Publisher contact information for the journal Ambio is: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands.
Keywords for this news article include: Fukuoka, Japan, Asia, Agriculture, Agroforestry, Risk and Prevention.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

JAPANESE END-OF-MONTH STOCK REPORT

www.buysellsignals.com

Fruta Fruta (TO:2586 JPY229.0), Japan's 91st largest Food company by market cap, has climbed JPY70.0 (or 44.0%) in the past month to close at JPY229.0 on Monday.

The volume in the month equalled the average trading of 252.4 million shares.

The stock was the thirty-fifth highest performer in the Japanese market. Compared with the Nikkei 225 Index of 213 stocks which rose 2,522.3 points (or 6.6%) in the past month, this represented a relative price increase of 37.4%.

The price ranged between a low of 155.0 on Monday, 9 Jun and a high of 229.0 on Monday, 30 Jun. In the past month the market cap has jumped by JPY5 billion ($34.6 million) to JPY16.4 billion ($113.3 million).

SECTION 6 CORPORATE PROFILE

6.1 Activities

FRUTA FRUTA INC. imports, processes and sells Amazon fruit frozen pulp. The National Brand segment sells its own branded products, with Amazon fruits as its materials, to mass merchandisers, supermarkets, convenience stores and other retailers. The Agroforestry Marketing segment sells frozen fruit pulp and its processing products to eating out shops and food manufacturers, as well as sells to variety of companies the products other than frozen fruit pulp that can be in the field of agroforestry as raw materials. The Direct Marketing segment include the operation of Furutta Furutta Acai Cafe, Furutta Furutta Acai factory and other direct stores, as well as mail order using its own Website. It is 91st largest Food company by market capitalisation in Japan.

ADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares Traded

Annual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)

Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)

TSR: Total Shareholder Returns is expressed as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and dividend

Volume Index (VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the period

Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

urn:contentItem:67VB-21H1-JBSP-143B-00000-00Studies from Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute Yield New Data on Soil Science and Plant Nutrition (Effects of Soil Types and Fertility Management Practices On Soil Silicon Availability and Banana Silicon Uptake)2023-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - SOIL SCIENCE AND PLANT NUTRITIONStudies from Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute Yield New Data on Soil Science and Plant Nutrition (Effects of Soil Types and Fertility Management Practices On Soil Silicon Availability and Banana Silicon Uptake)


2023 MAR 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- Current study results on Life Sciences - Soil Science and Plant Nutrition have been published. According to news reporting originating from Tsukuba, Japan, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Although silicon (Si) is one of soil abundant constituents and one of the key elements enhancing plant disease resistance, banana uptake of Si is limited by soil Si availability. It remains unclear what factors regulates soil Si availability and whether banana Si uptake increases with increasing soil Si availability in home garden soils."


Financial support for this research came from Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, "To test whether soil Si availability and banana leaf SiO2 contents are affected by soil types or fertility management practices, we measured (1) banana leaf SiO2 contents along the gradient of livestock inputs in Andisols of Tanzania and (2) water extractable Si, phosphate-buffer extractable Si, and banana leaf SiO2 in the home garden soils with different degree of volcanic ash admixing and with/without leguminous trees in Indonesia (East Java and East Kalimantan). Livestock dung application increased banana leaf SiO2 contents in the Tanzanian home gardens. Water extractable Si increased with increasing soil pH, but soil phosphate-buffer extractable Si and banana leaf SiO2 contents were strongly regulated by oxalate-extractable Si and andic properties in the Indonesian home gardens. Effects of companion trees (agroforestry) increased banana leaf SiO2 only in two of three Andisols (Java)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results suggest that banana leaf SiO2 contents could be primarily regulated by admixing degree of volcanic parent materials rich in weatherable minerals, but that banana leaf SiO2 contents could also be increased by inputs of livestock dung rich in Si (Tanzania) and agroforestry (Indoensia)."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Effects of Soil Types and Fertility Management Practices On Soil Silicon Availability and Banana Silicon Uptake. Soil Science & Plant Nutrition, 2023. Soil Science & Plant Nutrition can be contacted at: Taylor & Francis Ltd, 2-4 Park Square, Milton Park, Abingdon OR14 4RN, Oxon, England. (Wiley-Blackwell - www.wiley.com/; Soil Science & Plant Nutrition - onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1747-0765)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kazumichi Fujii, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Tsukuba, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Yuri Ichinose, Kazuna Arai, Ken Komatsu, Chie Hayakawa, Dionisio de Guzman Alvindia, Kyoko Watanabe and Arief Hartono.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1080/00380768.2023.2175177. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Tsukuba, Japan, Asia, Soil Science and Plant Nutrition, Life Sciences, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute.

urn:contentItem:6D0W-0RS1-JBMY-H4F1-00000-00Southeast Asian leaders’ political orientation towards the environmental policy outcome2025-09-09T21:02:49Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisPg. 343-358Southeast Asian leaders’ political orientation towards the environmental policy outcome

Declaration of conflicting interestsThe author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

FundingThe author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

ORCID iDDini Tiara Sasmi https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3280-8202

Dini Tiara SasmiMoyan ShiABSTRACT

In this paper, we present an analysis of the leaders’ backgrounds shaping their decisions towards environmental policy outcomes of nascent democracies such as countries in Southeast Asia, with a specific focus on leaders’ traits and socio-economic conditions. Drawing on factors that influence a leader's decision-making process, including external factors such as social and economic and internal factors (cognitive or traits), this study explores the variation of quality of environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asian countries. Our findings suggest that the level of development negatively affects environmental policy outcomes, while democratic conditions do not play a significant role. We also find that leaders’ age and level of education negatively affect environmental policy outcomes, whereas gender is not correlated with the quality of the environment. This research provides valuable insights into the environmental policy landscape of Southeast Asia and offers recommendations for policymakers seeking to enhance environmental policy outcomes in the region.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

The existing body of literature exploring the correlation between the political ideology of parties in power and the outcomes of climate policy is vast, but unfortunately, most studies have been conducted in the context of Western countries. There is a conspicuous gap in the research when it comes to nascent emerged democracies, such as those found in Southeast Asia, which hinders our ability to fully understand how political leaders in these regions perform with respect to environmental issues. Consequently, there are compelling reasons why we need to shift our focus to Southeast Asia for our studies. Firstly, the region comprises nascent emerging democracies with distinct cultural, historical, and governmental administrative characteristics, making it challenging to directly apply findings from Western developed countries. In consolidated democracies, the responsibility for safeguarding key environmental domains often rests with local governments, and citizens expect officials to prioritize environmental values, exerting pressure when these responsibilities are neglected. However, the dynamics of environmental stewardship in nascent democracies can differ significantly (Assetto et al., 2003).

Secondly, in terms of globalization, there are notable differences between Western developed countries and East and Southeast Asian nations. Citizens in Western developed countries are typically more actively informed through the media, while individuals in East and Southeast Asia tend to have a more passive engagement with receiving messages and information through the media (Inoguchi & Marsh, 2007). This discrepancy undoubtedly affects how they perceive and engage with global issues such as climate change. Finally, more and more powerful leaders from Asia are appearing in the global political arena, notably Xi Jinping in China, Joko Widodo in Indonesia, Erdogan in Turkey, and Mohammed Bin Salman Al Saud in Saudi Arabia. Thus it can be seen that Asia will play bigger role on the world stage in the future. Therefore, it is crucial for us to expand our research to encompass a broader range of diverse regional studies. By widening our scope of analysis, we can acquire a more comprehensive understanding of leaders, regional studies, and government studies.

In this study, we examine various mechanisms explaining the variation of environmental policy outcomes in democracies. In particular, at the system level, we examine the mechanisms proposed in the literature by which democratic institutions and economic development shape environmental policy outcomes. At the individual level, we re-examine theories about the relationship between democratic leaders’ traits (age, gender, and education) and environmental policy outcomes. We argue that the existing theories of democratic institutions and leaders are not sufficient to explain the variation of environmental policy outcomes in nascent democracies. Instead, we propose that the level of economic development is an effective indicator of environmental policy outcomes, at least for South East Asian countries, and the relationship between the two follows an inverted-U shape pattern.

This paper is organized as follows. The first section briefly introduces the prominence of environmental issues in the field of political science in Southeast Asian countries. The second section reviews the existing literature on how democratic institutions and leaders shape environmental policy outcomes. In the third section, we describe our theoretical framework analysis. The fourth section presents our research design. The fifth section presents our core argument and results. The sixth section concludes with our empirical findings as well as our recommendations.

Literature review

Environmental issues are perhaps one of the most critical and complicated collective action problems faced by humankind, but unfortunately, there has been little consensus on the solution. It is common sense that environmental issues need not only strong governments’ dedication but also international cooperation. Despite the tremendous scholars’ efforts in searching for ways to produce a better environment, factors leading to better environmental policy outcomes remain a puzzle.

A growing number of studies examining environmental policy outcomes from a micro perspective have focused on the effects of leader traits on environmental policy outcomes. The existing literature has proposed plenty of theories explaining leaders’ traits and behavior. Most studies of leaders have been on the leader's propensity for survival in office or how his or her background may have influenced the decision to go to war or not (Clarke & Stone, 2008; De Mesquita et al., 2005; Morrow et al., 2008). Some studies determine how the experience of civil wars and military coups impacts a leader's ability to survive in office (Frantz & Stein, 2017; Sudduth, 2017). Others investigate how regime types influence the leader’s instability and their survival (De Mesquita & Siverson, 1995; Hollyer & Rosendorff, 2012; Kim & Kroeger, 2018).

While extensive literature on leaders revolves around leader survival and behavior, assessments of the relationship between leadership and their decision toward the environmental outcome are very limited. Studies, if any, focus mostly on how the leader's party affiliation influences their decision-making toward environmental policies (i.e Garmann, 2014; Knill et al., 2010). It is suggested that party affiliation has a significant impact on leaders’ policy choices on environmental issues. For example, the parties in power with left-wing orientation tend to support environmentally friendly policies, such as policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In addition, political parties with stronger environmental attitudes are more likely to enact more environmental regulations when in office (Garmann, 2014).

Some recent research on environmental policy has begun to explore the connection between leaders’ personal traits and policy outcomes. For example, a study conducted by Biscotti & D’Amico (2016) found that the environmental inclinations of political leaders are influenced by cognitive and motivational factors related to social identification processes. Additionally, Diaz-Serrano & Kallis (2022) discovered a significant correlation between leaders with business backgrounds and inadequate climate mitigation efforts. However, it is important to note that many of these studies have limitations owing to selection bias. They often focus solely on consolidated democracies or specific regions, which may not provide a comprehensive understanding of the relationship between leaders’ backgrounds and environmental policy outcomes. To address this gap, we propose examining different regions such as Southeast Asia, which are considered nascent democracies in comparison with Europe. By studying these regions, we can gain fresh insights into the influence of leaders’ backgrounds on environmental policy outcomes.

Gender is another factor that deserves our research attention. The theory of gender socialization suggests that women tend to have more concerns about environmental issues because women were given care-giver roles during their childhood socialization (i.e. Chodorow, 1978; Davidson & Freudenburg, 1996). If gender differences in environmental attitudes are indeed reflected in environmental politics, it is reasonable to expect that female leaders will be more inclined to support environmentally friendly policies, thus resulting in better policy outcomes. In fact, recent research provides indications supporting this notion, as countries with a higher representation of women in parliament tend to adopt more assertive environmental policies (Mavisakalyan & Tarverdi, 2019).

There has been extensive literature discussing the factors that influence environmental policy outcomes from a macro perspective. Among this literature, two prominent lines of inquiry emerge. The first line focuses on the impact of democracy, while the second line explores the role of economic development. The question of how democratic institutions influence environmental policy outcomes has generated conflicting evidence in the existing literature. In a democracy, politicians’ motivation to pursue short-term interests undermines environmental policy outcomes. For example, in the case of Myanmar, vote-seeking party elites prefer policies encouraging free trade and increased forestry industry investment rather than chasing long-term environmental goals (Wang & Myint, 2016). Although economic development has been a relatively high priority in Myanmar during times of financial crisis, the convergence of voters’ short-term interests and politicians’ incentives has impeded the effectiveness of environmental policies within democratic institutions.

On the other hand, democratic institutions do provide a channel for the voice of environmental groups, thereby promoting positive environmental policy outcomes. Despite the free-rider issue inherent in democratic systems, democracies tend to display greater cooperation on environmental issues compared with non-democracies (Bättig & Bernauer, 2009). While Bättig and Bernauer present a convincing mechanism for explaining environmental policy outcomes in Western democracies, we believe that their theories may suffer from selection bias. Much of the literature on democracy and the environment primarily focuses on developed Western democracies. For instance, the empirical analysis conducted by Bättig and Bernauer (2009) only covers 12 countries, with a majority of their samples representing developed democracies. In fact, the literature does not provide conclusive evidence regarding a concrete relationship between democratic institutions and environmental policy outcomes. As we discuss further below, democratic institutions both facilitate and constrain environmental policies.

The notion that democratic countries have a positive impact on the environment has always been an interesting topic of discussion However, the extent to which democracy can effectively resolve significant policy issues, both locally and internationally, depends on various factors such as the level of analysis, the nature of the issues, and the criteria used to evaluate policy performance. For instance, Lim & Tang (2002) theorize that democratization will have different result in countries that have authoritarian legacies. Lim posits that some adverse legacies from an authoritarian era create complex dynamics between democratization and environmental policy-making. In building his theory, he used descriptive analysis methods in explaining environmental cases in Korea, such as the Youngwol Dam project and the Wichon Industrial complex.

Arguments about how authoritarian legacy affects nascent democratic countries also appear in world politics articles by McCarthy (2014a). Similar to Lim, McCarthy used a descriptive analysis method in discussing environmental cases in Myanmar. He found that, contrary to the nature of democracy, Myanmar showed that democratization has no significant relations to better forestry governance. He argued this happened because Myanmar's transition to democracy conflicted with an economic crisis. Politicians will benefit directly from policies that encourage free trade and increased forestry industry investment at the expense of the environment and the most vulnerable members of society.

The relationship between economic development and the environment has also received much attention in early studies. Examples of the environmental degradation caused by economic development abound from the Industrial Revolution to the first half of the nineteenth century. However, the relationship between economic development and environmental quality is not a monotonic one. An Environmental Kuznets Curve suggests that the relationship between economic development and environmental quality is an inverted U-shape (Dinda, 2004). As income rises, environmental degradation first rises and then falls. Imagine if environmental quality were a luxury good; the demand for environmental quality would not always rise as income rose, but rather the demand for the luxury good of environmental quality would only occur when income reached a certain level.

Theoretical framework and hypotheses development

In this research, we intend to examine the theories of environmental policy outcomes at both macro and micro levels. At the micro level we explore the effects of leader characteristics, including age, gender and educational background, on environmental policy outcomes, while at the macro level we aspire to explore how economic conditions influence leaders’ behavior towards environmental policy.

Do democratic countries generate better environmental policy outcomes than other regimes? We do not believe that being democratic has a significant impact on environmental policy outcomes. We argue that the constraint and incentive mechanisms of democracy on environmental policy outcomes cancel each other out. We define two constraints of democratic institutions. The first major constraint is the inefficacy of the bureaucratic system. Democratic legislatures take relatively longer to pass legislation compared with authoritarian regimes. Competition among parties and interest groups makes it difficult for legislatures to pass ambitious environmental policies. In addition, even politicians who are friendly to environmental policies have difficulty promoting environmental policies that pursue long-term benefits when faced with voters who focus on short-term interests. The second constraint that may appear in democratic systems is regulatory rigidity and inflexibility. Rigid adherence to laws and regulations deters initiative and inventiveness. Additionally, it could offer the protection needed to escape accountability for mistakes. Arguably, the conflict of interest within the body of democracies will lead to low efficiency, which will therefore make environmental policy fail.

Although we argue that democracy does not have a significant impact on environmental policy outcomes, we do believe that democracy provides participants with incentives to pursue environmental policies in three ways. The first is through democratic legislature rules. By having legislature regulation in a democratic way, local environment groups such as the farmers, fishers and planters are able to participate in legislation. When there is a democratic election and legislature rules, local fishermen, for example, can strive for their goals through influencing local legislators and candidates. Thus, local fishermen could expect new regulations in favor of the maritime environment by selecting their own representatives.

Second, the free-market system can potentially promote environmental sustainability. Arguably, when a country adopts a democratic system, the state does not have a monopoly over the market, and this eventually will lead to economy stability. Self-interested people function in a free market economy through a network of interdependence. Suppose fishermen catch fish and sell them in the market; without the interference from the government, they can sell their products at the reasonable market price, just as explained by the invisible hand theory by Adam Smith. By functioning in their own best interests, consumers and producers will allocate resources efficiently for the benefit of the entire community. Without state intervention in the market producers such as farmers and fishers can maximize their profit production.

Third, democracy protects property rights. Suppose farmers produce high profits from their production; a party in a dictatorship regime would confiscate all of their wealth by imposing higher taxes. Under democratic governance, however, the Equality party would advocate lowering the tax for the farmers and only increase the tax based on the rules. The farmers then could vote for a party which would maximize their incentive and therefore defend their interest. Elections under democracy, hence, will be tools for farmers to calculate expected values and act upon them when deciding how much to invest. To conclude, there are three incentives for environmental groups in a democratic system: (1) the democratic legislature system; (2) the free market system; and (3) protection of property rights. Intuitively, we could expect that having democratic governance will increase the propensity of the environmental groups to achieve their goals.

However, in the case of nascent democratic countries where the economy is still developing or underdeveloped, we do not expect democracy to improve the environmental conditions because first, the positive and negative impacts of democratic institutions on the environment cancel each other out, and second, the pursuit of short-term interest drives the politician to temporarily ignore environmental legislation that only produces long-term returns. From the discussion above we therefore test the following hypothesis: H1:The level of democracy is not correlated with environmental policy outcomes.

At the macro level, we are interested in how democracy and macro-economic conditions play a role in environmental policy outcomes. Specifically, we are skeptical about the theories explaining the impact of democracy on environmental policy outcomes in the existing theories. It is assumed that economic development will bring many problems for the environment since states will maximize all resources to gain capital. In contrast, we argue that in a democratic environment, the Environmental Kuznets Curve is a better theory to explain the variation in environmental policy outcomes. H2:The level of economic development is negatively associated with environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asian countries.

Arguably, gender is one of the most frequently addressed aspects in the literature of leadership. This is partly due, perhaps, to the lack of female heads of state in most of dataset before World War II. Although we have witnessed their numbers increasing in each decade, today the number is still considered small. Most research on the impact of gender on leadership diversity has focused either on aggression or on financial performance. There has been little, if any, exploration of how female leaders make decisions regarding environmental policy. This raises the question of whether the classical perspective regarding female nurturing and gentle characteristics applies to how they protect the environment. It is an important area of inquiry, as it has implications for how we view and support female leaders in addressing critical global challenges. In this discussion, we will examine the environmental protection and sustainability policies of each of these leaders.

The classical perspective on women often associates them with a stereotypical image of being nurturing and gentle. The debate centers on the assumption that higher levels of testosterone are associated with male aggressive behavior. This assumption is explained by Chang et al., (2011) using the sexual selection theory, which states that males are more likely to advocate armed conflict than women. In a similar vein, Brollo and Troiano's (2016) research uncovered that female politicians in Brazil exhibited lower tendencies towards dishonesty and opportunism compared with their male counterparts. Furthermore, they were less inclined to engage in short-term, strategic thinking during political elections. If women leaders are less likely to engage in corruption, does this also apply to the environmental problem? Is it possible that women leaders have better environmental policies than men?

In Southeast Asia, the representation of women in the highest political positions, such as president or prime minister, has been limited, with only five individuals holding such posts to date. This small sample size may pose challenges in terms of external validity when conducting quantitative analyses. Women involved in politics demonstrate a higher propensity to engage in policies that yield long-term advantages; consequently, female leaders tend to achieve more favorable outcomes in environmental policy. If this holds, women in politics will put more focus on environmental issues, thereby enhancing environmental policy outcomes by raising the issue salience. We expect that women will produce better environmental policy outcomes than men. H3:Female leaders are positively associated with environmental policy outcomes.

And what about age? Will maturity in age contribute positively to environmental decisions? Horowitz et al., (2005) suggested that there are strong relations between a leader's age and the decisions they make during international conflict. He also stated that, surprisingly, older leaders are much more likely to engage in militaristic action whenever institutional factors are not taken into account. This finding leads us to ponder, does the age of the leaders also play the same role when it comes to environmental regulations? A study by Biscotti & D’Amico (2016) that used Italy as the unit of analysis found that older leaders indicate a lower environmental propensity than younger ones. However, we are afraid that their theory cannot be widely applied because their empirical data only considers Italian leaders. In this research, we would like to re-exam Biscotti and D’Amico's theory using samples in Southeast Asian nascent democracies. H4:Older leaders are negatively associated with environmental policy outcomes.

Aside from leaders’ age, other factors could also play a pivotal role in influencing leaders’ propensities regarding the environmental issue. It is commonly known that education is positively associated with environmental principles and a commitment to addressing environmental issues, but it would be a leap to infer that every well-educated leader will be likely to support environmental regulation. For instance, a study by Constant & Tien, (2010) demonstrated that leaders’ foreign education is correlated with the amount of foreign direct investment that enters their home nations. A question arises then,whether by supporting foreign direct investment, we could assume that leaders with foreign education or in particular leaders with higher education will prefer economic growth over a sustainable policy that would save the environment. Based on the above arguments, we thus test the following hypothesis: H5:Leaders with higher education levels will produce better environmental policy outcomes.

Research design

As we have noted, research on political leaders lacks regional study. The leaders–environment hypothesis is especially challenging to assess when a specific region is in focus. Similarly, the relationship between democracy and environmental policy outcomes presents contradicting results based on regions. While studies on developed Western democracies suggest a positive relationship between the level of democracy and environment, especially forestry policy, evidence in the Southeast Asia region demonstrates the opposite (McCarthy, 2014b). Taking Myanmar as the sample, McCarthy stated that democratization has no significant relations with a better forestry governance. He argued that this happened because Myanmar's transition to democracy conflicted with an economic crisis and democratization in Myanmar has an authoritarian legacy. He argues that this is due to the pursuit of short-term economic interest during the economic crisis offsetting the positive impact of democratization. We believe that the empirical result of the democracy–environment hypothesis is likely to differ owing to differences in sample selection and different definitions of the dependent variable (policy output vs. policy outcome). We opt for a more specific approach, focusing on countries in Southeast Asia, examining the impacts of leaders’ traits, democracy and the level of development on environmental policy outcomes. Our panel time series data contain the variation of variables by country over time.

As carbon emissions have become the center focus of both domestic and international climate change issues, this research focuses on carbon emissions since it is a symbolic mark of environment quality. Our dependent variable, environmental policy outcomes, is measured by carbon emissions per capita from the World Bank database. Holding all else constant, a decrease in carbon emissions per capita indicates an improvement in environmental policy outcomes. We adopt the LEADS dataset as our source of leaders’ traits data. In particular, we will test the effects of leaders’ gender, age and level of education. In our dataset, gender is a dummy variable, in which 0 represents being male and 1 represents being female. The age variable is a set of continuous integers. The level of education is an ordinal variable ranging from 0 to 4 in which 0 represents the lowest level of education while 4 represents the highest level of education. As for the measure of democracy. We adopt the polyarchy score from the V-Dem project as our measure of democracy. Lastly, we control the level of development. Gross domestic product (GDP) per capita is used as a measure of development since it reflects the entire degree of country development.

A linear model was chosen because it provides a more intuitive description of how changes in the explanatory variable affect the response variable. Our sample comprises 11 Southeast Asian countries. Our primary empirical model seeks to elucidate environmental policy outcomes by considering leaders’ gender, age and education, as well as the political regime, while controlling for the level of development. By including these variables, along with the political regime and level of development as controlling factors, our model aims to capture the multifaceted nature of environmental policy outcomes in the context of Southeast Asian countries.

Results and discussionAssessing the impact of leader's background and their political orientation towards the environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asian countries

We begin our analysis by quantifying the influence of leadership on the key indicator of national contribution to mitigating global climate change: carbon dioxide (CO2) emission. It should be noted that our research does not concentrate on the examination of a singular policy; rather, it centers on investigating the influence of leadership traits on the general environmental quality. Primarily, leaders affect environmental quality through the implementation of a comprehensive array of environmental policies. By analyzing the interplay between leaders’ backgrounds, socio-economic conditions, and environmental policy outcomes, we aim to shed light on the complex dynamics shaping environmental governance in Southeast Asian countries. Table 1 shows the result.

Table 1.

The effects of leaders’ traits and socio-economic conditions on environmental policy in Southeast Asian countries.

Standard errors in parentheses.

*** p < 0.01, ** p < 0.05, * p < 0.1.

Table 1 illustrates the effects of leaders’ gender, age and education, democracy, and level of development on environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asian countries. The empirical result confirms our hypothesis regarding leaders’ age by which older leaders tend to produce worse environmental outcomes as the coefficient on age is positive and significant, meaning that as their age increases, leaders are more likely to adopt environment-unfriendly policies. For leaders’ traits, being male does not significantly bring positive or negative effects on carbon emissions per capita, meaning that we do not see a significant relationship with leaders’ gender. However, this could be due to the limited number of female leaders in our sample. Among 141 Southeast Asian leaders in our sample, only three are female. We believe that our hypothesis, which posits that female leaders tend to produce superior environmental policy outcomes, could be further tested by adopting a larger sample size once the data becomes available.

We recognize that this limitation may lead to an inadequate representation of the influence of female leadership on environmental policy outcomes. As a result, in the upcoming section, we will present a concise summary of the environmental initiatives undertaken by each of these female leaders in addressing environmental concerns. Moreover, we contend that our hypothesis, which posits that female leaders tend to generate more favorable environmental policy outcomes, could be subjected to further examination by employing a larger sample size once the data becomes accessible.

Exploring the role of women in environmental policy making in Southeast Asia

Just like any other part of the world, women's entry into political leadership in Southeast Asia countries is a relatively new phenomenon. Despite their policies not being exclusively focused on the environment, we contend that each of the female leaders in Southeast Asia has exerted a significant influence in promoting sustainability and environmental protection in their respective countries. There is evidence that they emphasize the significance of preserving natural resources for future generations in their policies.

In Philippines, Corazon Aquino, the first female leader in the region, prioritized environmental protection during her presidency by signing into law several policies aimed at preserving the country's natural resources. Her successor, Miaria Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, continued this trend by promoting renewable energy sources, implementing climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction policies, and protecting the country's natural resources through policies such as organic farming and agroforestry. Megawati Soekarno Putri, the former president of Indonesia, banned illegal logging, promoted renewable energy and established marine conservation initiatives. Halimah Yacob, Singapore's current president, has spoken about the importance of environmental protection and sustainability, although the country has had a focus on sustainability regardless of the gender of its leaders. Finally, Dng Th Ngc Thnh, the former president of Vietnam, implemented the “Green Sunday” campaign and promoted renewable energy and energy-efficient technologies to reduce carbon emissions.

In general, women leaders in Southeast Asian countries have showed their support for environmental protection. Nevertheless, the current state of knowledge on this matter remains lacking. We acknowledge that relying solely on a literature review may not suffice for making a definitive judgement. In light of this, for future research, it is important to investigate whether there exists a discernible difference in environmental policy performance between female and male leaders in Southeast Asia. It is worth noting that such an inquiry cannot be reduced to a mere binary, as constitutional provisions play a decisive role in shaping environmental outcomes. To obtain a more comprehensive understanding of this issue, a rigorous data-driven analysis and quantifiable metrics must be employed to evaluate whether female leaders in emerging democracies such as those found in Southeast Asia truly exhibit superior environmental policy performance vis-à-vis their male counterparts.

As we move forward, the empirical result confirms our hypothesis of leaders’ age that older leaders tend to produce worse environmental outcomes as the coefficient on age is positive and significant, meaning that as their age increases, leaders are more likely to adopt environment-unfriendly policies. Moreover, surprisingly, empirical research suggests that leaders’ levels of education are inversely associated with environmental policy outcomes, with more educated leaders resulting in higher levels of carbon emission per capita. We posit that the contrasting evidence stems from the influence of economic ideas and beliefs shaped by individuals’ educational backgrounds. As elucidated in the existing literature (Li et al., 2020), leaders with higher levels of education are more inclined to embrace rapid liberal reforms, thereby fostering the expansion of the capitalist economy. Accelerated industrial growth in Southeast Asian countries, where the capital economy was in its early phases over the past decades, resulted in the degradation of environmental quality, as indicated by increased carbon emissions. It should be noted, however, that our sample excludes Western democracies, which are primarily developed economies.

The predicted value of carbon emissions per capita is plotted in Figure 1. The explanation of this linear relationship is pretty straightforward: as GDP per capita increases, the value of carbon emissions per capita increases, showing a positive correlation between the level of development and environmental policy outcomes. It should be noticed that despite the fact that we compared the effects of gender on the relationship between the two, being female did not significantly increase or decrease the level of carbon emissions as our empirical evidence suggests. Therefore, we cannot conclude that being male generally produces better environmental policy outcomes. We acknowledge that the conclusion we have drawn may be hasty owing to the insufficient representation of female samples. Potential future research endeavors could address this limitation by increasing the number of female leaders included in the sample, thus allowing for further investigation.

Figure 1.

The predicted value of carbon emissions per capita vs. GDP per capita across gender.

Assessing economy impact on environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asian countries

At the macro level, it is confirmed that democracy is unrelated to environmental policy outcomes. It should be emphasized that the scope of this study is confined to Southeast Asian countries; therefore the results do not apply to all situations worldwide. Our focus here is to emphasize the office-seeking incentive mechanism of democratic leaders. Democratic leaders, driven by the goal of securing re-election, strive to fulfill the preferences of the majority. However, it is important to emphasize that the policy preferences of the majority, whether they lean towards environmental concerns or economic development, vary between industrialized nations and developing or underdeveloped countries. Since democratic leaders in less developed or developing countries face tremendous pressure with regard to economic performance, they are more likely to ignore far-sighted environmental policies that are considered as luxury goods. In the cases of Western democracies, as the economic development reaches a certain high level, leaders will turn to focus more on environmental improvement as their constituents’ short-term interests, economic well-being, are mostly satisfied.

Our above argument regarding the relationship between economic development and environmental policy outcomes is substantiated by our regression results. The GDP per capita produces a positive impact on the carbon emission per capita, which indicates that the level of development brings worse environmental conditions. Likewise, our argument here is limited to the Southeast Asian context. As suggested in the Environmental Kuznets Curve Theory, we believe that there is an inverted-U shape relationship between the level of development and environmental quality. The demand for environmental quality increases as the level of development reaches a certain level so that the level of development will eventually lead to better environmental policy outcomes. However, by observing the unique history of Southeast Asian countries, we believe that the Environmental Kuznets Curve Theory may not apply to this region specifically as it applies to a model containing countries around the world.

We further develop a model including the polynomial to investigate the relationship between economic development and environmental policy outcomes. The Environmental Kuznets Curve Theory suggests an inverted-U shape relationship between the two. However, our findings in Southeast Asian cases do not support this claim. The regression results are shown in Table 2. What is interesting here is that our empirical results indicate that the level of democracy does not have a statistically significant effect on environmental policy outcomes, as its coefficient (−0.133) is not significant with a p-value bigger than 0.1.

Table 2.

The effects of leaders’ traits and socio-economic conditions on environmental policy in Southeast Asian countries (including polynomial terms).

Standard errors in parentheses.

*** p < 0.01, ** p < 0.05, * p < 0.1.

While democratization was found to have no substantial link with environmental policy outcomes, macroeconomic factors were found to have a considerable influence. This implies that economic growth may trump the need to promote sustainable policies, particularly in countries transitioning from authoritarian governments to democracies. As much as any other change in society, environmental policies depend on various factors: public attitudes, economic and social conditions, even historical background. Just one factor could contribute to unsuccessful environmental policies implementation.

We believe that this is why the level of democracy alone shows no significant correlation to environmental policies. There are more things that need to be taken into consideration, for instance public support. Without support from the public, governments are unlikely to pass and implement robust environmental regulations which might constrict citizens’ lifestyles, limit their rights, or raise their taxes. This finding also highlights the heterogeneous effects of economic growth on environmental policy outcomes. In other part of Asia that experienced rapidly growth during industrialization, such as in China and India, economic growth has led to an increase in carbon emissions as well. As such, the need for sustainable policies and regulations is paramount, as economic growth can potentially exacerbate environmental issues and undermine efforts to address them.

Moving forward, we make a prediction of the value of environmental policy outcomes as a function of GDP per capita. The prediction result is shown in Figure 2, where it can be seen that the prediction produces an unbalanced U-shaped relationship, which completely contradicts the Environmental Kuznet Curve Theory. However, we do not intend to reject the prediction of the Environmental Kuznet Curve Theory as it focuses on a broader, worldwide level, while our findings are specific to Southeast Asian countries. By highlighting these distinctions, we aim to provide insights that are region-specific and contextual, contributing to a deeper understanding of the relationship between economic development and environmental policy outcomes in Southeast Asia.

Figure 2.

The effect of GDP per capita on environmental policy outcomes.

As Southeast Asian countries modernized, they began to change their businesses, shedding their reliance on natural resources in favor of industrialization. The environmental conditions improved in the early phases of industrialization as traditional sectors that over-exploited natural resources were abandoned, which is why the first half of our prediction reveals that the environmental situation will improve as GDP per capita climbs. However, as industrialization progresses, environmental degradation progressively grows and then decreases once a specific level is reached, which explains why the environment continues to degrade in the second half of the prediction plot.

Countries in the Southeast Asian region have a unique legacy in terms of economic development. This uniqueness is a result from the past events before and after World War II, when most Southeast Asian economies relied heavily on the extraction of natural resources, such as oil and natural gas reserves, timber, sugar and palm-oil plantation. The European colonialization of this region played a significant role in shaping its economic landscape. As a result of colonial rule, the region became a resource extraction hub, with the extracted resources being exported to European countries. This colonial influence had far-reaching implications for resource exploitation and environmental change, as it brought about political and administrative developments that continue to impact these aspects to this day (Bryant 1998). Moreover, the presence of different colonial powers introduced varying techniques and approaches to resource management, further exacerbating the situation. As a result, despite not reaching the same level of industrialization as Western countries, environmental conditions in Southeast Asian countries may have been significantly worse owing to historical factors and patterns of resource exploitation established during colonial rule, giving Southeast Asian leaders a stronger influence over environmental policies.

Conclusion and recommendation

Southeast Asia possesses a distinctive and abundant environment, characterized by its unique, diverse, and resource-rich natural endowments. The region features a remarkably long coastline with a diversified marine and coastal habitat. With all of its natural riches, the Southeast Asia area holds critical responsibilities in global environmental policies. The environmental policies literature has progressively grown more complex, extending its influence to every sector of the economy and reaching every corner of nations including the Southeast Asia region. To ensure that new scientific knowledge and policy evaluation align with the goals of environmental protection, it is crucial to comprehensively examine all relevant aspects, including the role of leaders. By considering various factors and the leadership's impact, a holistic approach can be adopted to advance environmental policy outcomes and promote sustainable practices.

As discussed throughout the text, our empirical evidence suggests that, firstly, at the micro level, leader traits such as age and education background of leaders are negatively correlated with environmental policy outcomes. Additionally, we did not find evidence indicating that the gender of leaders and democracy have a beneficial impact on environmental policy outcomes. IWe want to emphasize the role of gender in environmental issues. Although our empirical evidence did not find a correlation between gender and environmental policy outcomes, we believe that different conclusions may be obtained if the coverage of the data is exapanded. Only three of the leaders in our sample are female, which is far from sufficient to establish the role of gender in environmental policy. We are currently unable to collect additional statistics on female leaders owing to data restrictions. We expect that in the future, as the data expand and become more accessible, scholars will be able to delve deeper into the mechanism of gender issues.

Secondly, at the macro level, economic development is generally negatively correlated with environmental policy outcomes, while the level of democratization does not have significant correlation with the environmental policy outcomes. Some of our findings are inconsistent with the previous literature, which we believe is reasonable because our study focuses only on 11 Southeast Asian countries. There is no guarantee, of course, that our model could apply to other leaders in different region, since differences exist in the historical background and economic development experiences among countries. Arguably, it is difficult to find a model that universally explains environmental policy outcomes for all countries. For this reason, we believe that there is an urgent need for scholars to broaden their regional studies in order to capture the best of the socio-political situations that differ and are distinct in each location.

urn:contentItem:5R0V-BNN1-DYN6-W0H8-00000-00Asian editorial excerpts2017-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisAsian editorial excerptsTOKYO, Nov. 20

Selected editorial excerpts from the Asia-Pacific press:

BONN, THE INTERSECTION (The Jakarta Post, Jakarta)

There was little excitement during the climate talks in Bonn. The Jubilation of Paris two years ago after participating countries agreed to form a global pact to reduce emissions in a bid to prevent more floods, heat waves and rising sea levels, has subsided.

As delegates prepared the rule book to implement the climate accord at the 23rd session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention on Climate Change, they were bracing for the impact of the United States' exit.

As one of the biggest emitters and among countries that has provided significant funding to the global movement, the US pullout from the climate accord...has shifted the balance of the world's largest diplomatic convention.

There was a ring of solidarity, shared by developed and developing countries, expressing their firm commitment to the Paris accord.

However, much more than commitment is needed.

Scientists said countries had barely budged in reducing their emissions.

Political obstacles may also hamper talks on the allocation of funding and technology necessary to support other countries in upholding the global goal.

The two-week talks in Bonn have shown that it is the big countries that are reluctant to carry out the commitments.

For Indonesia, which still relies on technology and funding to meet its own goals, however, this is no excuse to slow down efforts to reduce emissions, especially in the forestry sector. The government, along with the private sector and citizens, have made significant achievements in reducing forest fires and improving agroforestry partnerships that have also begun to benefit locals.

The innovation and partnerships to reduce emissions in forestry will benefit the country in sustaining its land and forests. Indonesia could then show the way forward in the climate fight.

(Nov. 20)

urn:contentItem:4NTJ-8RY0-TX7G-G390-00000-00J-Green 'rigged other bids'2007-05-26T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisPg. 1J-Green 'rigged other bids'Yomiuri

Prosecutors searched branch offices and other locations of the Japan Green Resources Agency (J-Green) Friday on suspicion of bid-rigging in two large-scale projects in Kumamoto and Shimane prefectures, following previous allegations of bid-rigging in forest road projects.

The latest allegations involve forestry and agricultural development projects in mountainous areas, adopted primarily by the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry. J-Green, an independent administrative entity under the ministry, took on the two projects in Ogunimachi, Kumamoto Prefecture, and Gotsu, Shimane Prefecture.

The Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office's special investigation squad has already arrested a former and a current J-Green official, along with four employees of its contractors, on suspicion of rigging bids for the agency's forest road survey consulting projects in fiscal 2005 and 2006. It now suspects J-Green also led bid-rigging in the two agroforestry projects.

For the Kumamoto Prefecture project, 5,700 hectares will be developed from fiscal 2003 to 2009 at a cost of 15.4 billion yen. The Shimane Prefecture project will cost 12 billion yen to develop 3,080 hectares from fiscal 2007 to 2013.

The prosecutors searched J-Green's Kyushu Branch Office in Fukuoka and the Kinki-Hokuriku Branch's Kyoto office, which ordered the projects.

urn:contentItem:4GMP-K6V0-00JR-G26T-00000-00<published>2005-07-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-09-09T21:02:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Africa seeks greater help from Japan in popularizing high-yield rice</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, July 15</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">African countries want Japan to increase its assistance to boost production of a resilient and high-yielding strain of rice known as new rice for Africa, or NERICA, the head of an Africa-based intergovernmental rice research group said Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A steady growth in output of NERICA would free Africa from paying $1 billion a year in rice imports, Kanayo Nwanze, director general of the Africa Rice Center in Benin, said on the sidelines of a Tokyo conference on agricultural development in Africa.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Japan, which has been actively involved in developing NERICA, voiced its support for boosting African agriculture during last week's summit of the Group of Eight nations in Scotland, where the G-8 leaders agreed to increase aid for the continent by $50 billion in 2010 from the 2004 level.</p><p>'Demand for rice in West Africa is growing about 6 percent per year, but production has not kept pace with such high growth,' Nwanze told reporters. 'Since the 1960s, rice imports in Africa have increased eightfold to 4 million tons per year at an annual cost of more than $1 billion.'</p><p> He said rice is the most rapidly growing food source in Africa, and that it is grown and consumed in about 40 countries in the continent.</p><p> Agriculture experts say NERICA has brought hope to millions of poor people in Africa. It adapts to the harsh growing environment in sub-Saharan Africa, where small farmers lack the means to irrigate the land and apply chemical fertilizers or pesticides.</p><p> Nwanze said his organization, in collaboration with Japan and other donors, plans to expand NERICA cultivation in Africa to 200,000 hectares in 2007 from the current 140,000 hectares, of which 120,000 are in western Africa and the rest in eastern Africa.</p><p> NERICA combines the ruggedness of local African rice strains with the high productivity traits of the Asian rice that laid the foundation for the Green Revolution in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s.</p><p> Along with Nwanze, the Tokyo conference brought together representatives from the Washington-based Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, Nairobi-based World Agroforestry Center, Syria-based International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas, India-based International Corps Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics as well as the Japanese government.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4G6T-3XR0-001X-J14G-00000-00<published>2005-05-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-09-09T21:02:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Pg. 3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AICHI EXPO 2005;<br/>Ecuador county showcases govt of the people</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Hiroyuki Ueba / Daily Yomiuri Staff Writer</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>NAGAKUTECHOC Aichi</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Public-participation-style political processes are vital to realizing economic, social and environmental sustainability, an indigenous Ecuadorean governor said said Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Auki Tituana was elected as the first indigenous governor of Cotacachi County in the South American country in 1996 and was invited to 2005 World Exposition Aichi as a guest lecturer.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Everyone, from children to the elderly, should be regarded as equals, and each citizen can contribute to the reformation and development of their society. It's difficult, but it's not impossible," Tituana said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Yomiuri</p></bodyText></section><p>Under his policy, all Cotacachi citizens--regardless of age, sex and ethnicity--are invited to an annual assembly to discuss various issues and participate in the decision-making process. The same policy is applied to five assemblies held once or twice a month, each of which deal with environmental issues and other specific topics, according to Tituana.</p><p>"Since 1996, the whole community of Cotacachi has made efforts for sustainable development," he said.</p><p>People in the county oppose mining, which will ultimately destroy the environment. So they have adopted an ordinance to conserve the county's ecosystem while promoting agroforestry programs and ecotourism to realize sustainable development by utilizing local nature, instead of depending on the mining industry.</p><p>Citizens of Cotacachi decide income tax rates and how the county's revenue is to be allocated. "The county's budget is preferentially allocated to programs for children, education and other social welfare programs," Tituana said. As governor, Tituana believes decisions made by the citizens themselves are absolute. He said, "Every citizen can do something to solve the problems faced by their society."<br/> <br/>Greek National Day</p><p>Greek economy and finance minister George Alogoskoufis visited 2005 World Exposition Aichi to celebrate the country's national day.</p><p>Alogoskoufis said at the ceremony that Greece and Japan could further develop both economic ties while maintaining a strong relationship as the two countries have much in common, such as their long history, respect for their ancestry and traditional culture. He also mentioned the success of the Athens 2004 Olympic Games, saying the expo is enjoying similar international success.</p><p>As part of the national day events, Greek theatrical performance group Roes performed a show titled, "Flows Milk, Flows Honey, Flows Milk." The performance was a mixture of dance and drama, embracing classical elements such as Greek mythology.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3XV7-DR90-00JR-G15B-00000-00<published>1999-11-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-09-09T21:02:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Scientists discover source of Victoria's killer weed</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NAIROBI, Nov. 9 Kyodo</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Scientists on Tuesday said they now know where a water plant blamed for killing Lake Victoria is getting many of its nutrients.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Satellite images have showed a flow of sediments entering the world's second largest freshwater lake from surrounding low-lying, deforested areas, said researchers from the Nairobi-based International Center for Research in Agroforestry (ICRAF).</p><p nitf:lede="true">The sediments contain the nutrients which feed floating hyacinths, water plants blamed for choking the lake's ecosystem.</p><p>The process is called eutrophication. It occurs when a body of water becomes enriched in dissolved nutrients that stimulate the growth of the aquatic plants.</p><p>Before the discovery of the nutrients' source, they had been widely believed to have originated from agricultural runoff.</p><p>'We noticed a dramatic plume of nitrogen- and phosphorous-rich sediments that are feeding the water hyacinth. This is one of the major causes of Lake Victoria's environmental demise,' said ICRAF Director General Pedro Sanchez.</p><p>'It surprised us to be able to apply land technology to lake water, and it led us in a new direction in terms of diagnosing Lake Victoria's environmental problems.'</p><p>The announcement was made jointly by the ICRAF and Washington-based Future Harvest, an organization aimed at showing the links between the environment and agriculture.</p><p>Lake Victoria, the chief reservoir of the Nile River, has been slowly dying over the last decade from the oversupply of nutrients and untreated sewage. The result has been a dwindling fish population, the spread of toxic algae and the rapid growth of floating hyacinths.</p><p>The plants are a problem because they deprive fish and plankton of oxygen and sunlight and lead to a reduction in the diversity of important aquatic plants. The weed's spread also blocks water traffic, further isolating remote regions.</p><p>In addition, the plant is blamed for stagnation of the lake's water, turning the shoreline into a breeding ground for mosquitoes that spread malaria and snails that carry a parasite that attacks the liver, lungs and eyes of humans.</p><p>So in effect, the plant threatens the livelihoods of at least 25 million people in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania who depend on the lake for water, food and business.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>$195 mil. needed for Afghan agricultural revival: ADB</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>MANILA, Aug. 10</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">An estimated $195 million over two years is needed to rehabilitate Afghanistan's agricultural sector in order to help the country fight poverty, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said in a statement released Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Manila-based bank said the estimate is based on a multi-donor assessment it coordinated that resulted in a draft final report outlining short- and medium-term frameworks for the war-torn country's economic recovery.</p><p nitf:lede="true">'There are enormous challenges, but Afghanistan's rural economy has substantial potential for recovery based on private sector-led growth, judicious management of water and other natural resources, and the provision of community-based, demand-driven services,' said ADB economist Allan Kelly, who led the assessment mission.</p><p>Kelly said a key challenge to attaining recovery for the country will be to find 'viable implementation and governance mechanisms.'</p><p>'This will require rebuilding an efficient institutional framework, revitalizing the roles of government at different levels, and fully exploiting the energy and initiative of rural communities and civil society,' he added.</p><p>The multi-donor report calls for a community-based, consultative approach to development and emphasizes the need to rehabilitate the country's irrigation systems that helped produce cash crops during the good years.</p><p>The report specifically urges the adoption of modern dry land farming technologies so that at least half the country's cereal needs can be met through rain-fed agriculture.</p><p>The report also includes detailed plans for technical assistance to support strategic planning, policy and institutional reform, and feasibility studies to prepare a medium-term investment program.</p><p>The assessment, conducted in two phases during February and April to May this year, comes on the heels of Afghanistan's efforts to emerge from decades of conflict and turmoil.</p><p>Agricultural output declined dramatically in the past decade.</p><p>Cereal yields, at about 0.6 tons per hectare of rain-fed land, are well below their potential. Irrigation systems are in disarray.</p><p>Agroforestry and horticulture, which once accounted for 40% of export earnings, now contribute only a small share to total agricultural output.</p><p>Livestock, which formerly provided an additional 40% of exports and was a principal source of cash income, is estimated to have been halved.</p><p>Afghanistan's rangelands have deteriorated due to drought, while fragile forests have been depleted by illegal logging and community demand for firewood.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:552D-1J51-JCF4-K28S-00000-00FEATURE: Woman Building Organic Links with Ghanaian Cacao Growers2012-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:02:49ZLexisNexisFEATURE: Woman Building Organic Links with Ghanaian Cacao GrowersTokyo, Feb. 27

Tomoko Hoshino was appalled to learn by chance the bitter reality of child labor in cacao production in Western Africa after watching a television documentary during a stay in London in 2001.

Coming as it did in the same year as the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, the recognition of the child labor issue drove home to Hoshino how little she, and many of her compatriots, know about affairs outside Japan.

For example, the production process of chocolate, made from roasted and ground cacao seeds, is not well known in Japan, although chocolate is a familiar item.

On the flip side, she thought, chocolate can raise awareness among Japanese of the close connection between their lives and people and environments overseas, including children who must work instead of attending school because of poverty.

Hoshino was motivated to launch an initiative to improve the status of producers by assisting in organic cacao production in Ghana.

"By bringing chocolate made from human- and earth-friendly cacao to Japanese consumers, I'd like to create a happy bond between producers and those who enjoy chocolate," says Hoshino, 49, founder and director of Choco-Revo International, a Tokyo-based general incorporated association.

Helping Producers

Set up in October 2011, Choco-Revo International not only supports a local nongovernmental organization but also is involved in the whole production process, ranging from cacao production and procurement to chocolate product development.

"We support cacao production that pays attention to the protection of forests and biodiversity and share information on our activities with all those involved in the supply chain," she says.

Choco-Revo International opts not to call for a boycott of chocolate made from cacao beans associated with child labor. It rather hopes to see voluntary participation of consumers in the efforts of businesses and NGOs to help cacao producers.

According to the Chocolate and Cocoa Association of Japan, cacao from Ghana accounts for about 80 pct of Japan's cacao imports. Ghana is the second largest cacao producer in the world, after Ivory Coast.

Around 1999, cacao prices plummeted due in part to market speculation, which led to an increase in the number of children being used as cheap labor, Hoshino says.

In Ghana, forests were badly damaged by persistent use of chemical fertilizers and clearing for the cultivation of cacao beans. Due to falling production and incomes, farmers could not afford school for their children, creating a vicious cycle that kept them in poverty.

Hoshino visited Ghana in 2007 for a firsthand look at a forest preservation project launched by Ricoh Co. , a Japanese office equipment manufacturer that promotes environmental protection as part of its social contribution.

In her visit to a local cacao production site, she witnessed scars of deforestation.

But thanks to the efforts of Ricoh and a local NGO since 2002, including reduction in the use of agricultural chemicals to raise soil nutrition, cacao production had increased. So had the number of children going to school.

According to a survey of local cacao producers conducted by Hoshino and Ricoh representatives in 2007, incomes had grown by two to eight times, while 90 pct of respondents claimed all their children go to school.

Hoshino is focusing on sustainable agroforestry.

Cacao trees can live 100 years if properly cared for. In the Hoshino-led project, many old cacao trees cultivated under nonorganic farming methods have been gradually replaced with seedlings, which are grown organically together with a diverse range of plants.

Network of Support

In 2008, Hoshino, then head of a preparatory committee to set up Choco-Revo International, held talks with representatives from a chocolate producer, a food trader and an NGO, all from Japan, on the development of products for Japan.

The following year, the initiative of her group was recognized by the Japan External Trade Organization as a development import project for which local information and financial support are provided by the government-linked organization to help the group prepare for imports.

With the aid of JETRO, Hoshino's group teamed up with COFA, a Ghanaian producer union that was the first in the African country to obtain organic certification in cacao production. It imported 3,000 pieces of chocolate produced in Ghana, and sold them at department stores operated by Marui Group Co. and Takashimaya Co. in January 2010.

In 2011, backed in part by Japanese companies, 30,000 cacao seedlings were planted in land owned by COFA member farmers. They are growing well and will start producing cacao in about five years.

The network of support for cacao producers in Ghana is growing steadily.

This year, on Feb. 14, St. Valentine's Day, chocolates from Choco-Revo International went on sale at three department store chains, including Odakyu Department Store Co. Chocolates made in collaboration with Mary Chocolate Co. were also released.

In Japan, women customarily give chocolates to men on St. Valentine's Day.

"Not only chocolate," Hoshino says. "When you choose a variety of products, I hope you exercise your imagination and consider by whom and how they were produced."
